intro: Buchnera bequaertii, commonly known as the green alga, is a unicellular photosynthetic organism belonging to the Chlorophyta division. It possesses chloroplasts that contain chlorophyll a and chlorophyll b, enabling it to perform photosynthesis efficiently. This alga is typically found in freshwater environments, such as ponds and lakes, where it thrives in well-lit conditions. Its simple structure includes a cell wall composed of cellulose and a nucleus enclosed by a nuclear envelope. Buchnera bequaertii plays a vital role in aquatic ecosystems by contributing to primary production and serving as a food source for various microorganisms and small aquatic animals.
